doc.title: Trade recommendations\*
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Euro Cash French surprise disrupted summer carryEuro Cash French surprise disrupted summer carry_2025-08-29

passages.text: Since our last publication two weeks ago, German yields declined with a modest outperformance of the intermediate sector, with the dovish messaging from the Fed and the French politics being the main driver of the move (Figure 1). Cross- market, US yields outperformed, with chair Powell delivering a dovish speech at the Jackson Hole symposium further opening the door for a Fed cut in September.
Figure 1: German yields declined since our last publication two weeks ago on the back of dovish Fed messaging and French politics back under the spotlight

10Y German yields have rallied around 6bp over the past couple of weeks to the \(2.70\%\) and are at their average levels for the past month. DM market focus next week will be on US payrolls and implications for the Fed's reaction function but we note that over the past few months 10Y German yields have been non- directional with 10Y UST yields (Figure 2). We expect this lack of directionality to persist as ECB is effectively at where it sees the neutral- policy rate and our expectation of limited term premia to be priced in the intermediate sector of the German curve.

We remain neutral on duration and maintain a modest bullish bias on 10Y German yields and would look to fade any term- driven sell- off in the intermediate sector. However, from a relative valuation standpoint we note that the 2s/10s curve looks very modestly too flat vs. front end yields (1Yx1Y €STR) and adjusting for the ECB balance sheet (Figure 3).

Figure 2: US payrolls are in focus next week, but we expect the lack of directionality between 10Y German and 10Y UST yields to persist 10Y par Germany yield regressed against 10Y UST benchmark yield; past 3M; %
Figure 3: We stay neutral duration with the 2s/10s curve very slightly too flat vs. the level of front end yields and adjusting for the ECB balance sheet

Intra- EMU spreads came under pressure since our last weekly in mid- August with most of the widening happening following the surprise confidence vote announcement by French PM Bayrou on Monday 25 August.

We have been recommending light outright OW intra- EMU/€- SSA exposures over summer as we didn't find the risk/reward attractive for carry exposures given limited carry/tight valuations and OW positioning. Also, we had preferred modest OW intra- EMU/€- SSA exposures with at least partial hedge vs. Uw France or Uw Italy to reduce beta to broader risk markets and benefit from any escalation in political noise in France. Our partial hedge strategy was vindicated over the past week given the escalation of political uncertainty in France. Given our expectation of ongoing political uncertainty in France over the coming weeks, we stick with our current intra- EMU/€- SSA strategy of low- beta OW with partial hedges with Uw France/Italy for the time being (see French politics - scenarios and implications for the macro, rates and FX outlook, 28 Aug, for details of French political scenarios and market implications).

We strongly believe that the ongoing French political developments will remain a French idiosyncratic story unless we get the tail risk disruptive scenarios. We, therefore, expect limited contagion to rest of intra- EMU spreads, as has been the case during this week's widening.

On positioning, as per our latest client survey, 28 August, European real money investors modestly reduced their OW intra- EMU exposure, with current OW exposures still close to the highest levels seen since early- 2022 (Figure 4). The current OW positioning could expose intra- EMU spreads to near- term widening pressure on liquidations in the event of any further widening on French political uncertainty.

On issuance, after the typical summer lull, the pace of Euro area sovereign issuance has started to pick- up in the second half of August, slightly earlier than has been observed in recent years, and is expected to further increase in September in line with typical historical dynamics (Figure 5). Overall, we expect supply pressures over the rest of 2025 to be materially lower than 1H25 given strong issuance frontloading, with \(\sim 76\%\) gross issuance already covered.
Figure 4: European investors OW exposure is still close to the highest levels seen since early 2022Net exposure of Euro area investors to peripherals vs. core, %
Source: J.P. Morgan European Client Survey, 28 August
Figure 5: Euro area sovereign issuance pace has started to pick-up in the second half of August and is expected to further increase in September in line with typical historical dynamics

We keep low beta OW exposures via OW 10Y Spain \((100\%)\) vs. 10Y Italy \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) and OW 10Y EU \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) . This week we take profit on OW 10Y Belgium \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) . As a risk- off hedge, we keep 3s/10s Italy steepener vs. Germany.

French spreads widened sharply post the surprise confidence vote announcement by PM Bayrou on Monday evening with the 10Y France- Germany spread widening some 10bp to around 80bp. However, this is still below the wides of close to 90bp seen during peak political noise around 2025 budget in early January 2025. After the recent widening, 10Y France- Germany spread is now screening more than 10bp too wide on our fair value framework

(Figure 6), which in our view reflects the repricing of political uncertainty risk premia. Also based on our sovereign risk index (see 2025 Euro Cash Outlook for details of index), we find French spreads around 10bp too wide (Figure 7), reflecting similar political uncertainty risk premia. The confidence vote announcement was a surprise but as we outlined in our 2H25 outlook we had expected an increase in political noise and modest widening in French spreads at some point around 2026 budget discussions.
Figure 6: French spreads are now screening more than 10bp too wide on our fair value framework, reflecting heightened political uncertainty risk premia
Residual from regressing 10Y France spread vs. Germany against 10Y wtd. peripheral spread vs. Germany (X1), 10Y Germany yield (X2) and 2024 France election dummy\* (X3); past 5Y; bp

Figure 7: France has historically traded quite dear on our sovereign risk framework, but 10Y France - Germany is now trading around 10bp too wide after the recent moves, reflecting increased political uncertainty risk premia

\(^\ast \mathrm{Y} = 0.18^\ast \mathrm{X}1 + 4.98^\ast \mathrm{X}2 + 28.1^\ast \mathrm{X}3 + 15.2;\) R- squared: \(93\%\) . The France 2024 election dummy variable is defined as 1 since 10 June 2024 and 0 before that as Macron called snap parliamentary elections on Sunday 9 June 2024 Source: J.P. Morgan.
Source: See Euro Cash 2025 Outlook for details on the sovereign risk index framework

Figure 8below shows our estimates of 10Y France- Germany spread in a steady state over the next 1- 2 months under various political scenarios. From a market point of view the key focus will be the fiscal agenda under the various outcomes and from a big picture perspective we think the most likely outcomes would result in only modest fiscal slippage relative to our forecast. We stress that there is high uncertainty around the outcomes given the surprise confidence vote call, lack of polls and lack of clarity on party groupings/manifestos in case of an early election.

In our view, the most likely scenario in the event that the Bayrou government falls is Macron will try to nominate a new PM. If the newly nominated PM is able to survive a confidence vote in the parliament, then we believe 10Y France- Germany spread will likely remove most of the political risk premia currently priced in and move back to the 65- 75bp range seen over the past few months.

If a new lower house election is called, our judgement is that a RN relative majority will be the most likely outcome. However, given the relative majority, it is unclear if RN will be able to find external support to govern or will face no- confidence motion leading to a dysfunctional lower house. Under such a scenario, we believe it will be hard for RN to deliver a confrontational fiscal approach but we still expect the market to price ongoing political uncertainty risk premia with 10Y spread staying around 80bp. Under the less likely scenario

of RN absolute majority, we believe that RN will have a choice to make, to either decide to take a confrontational fiscal stance or to take a more prudent fiscal stance with the aim to have a strong showing at the 2027 Presidential election. Our bias is to assume that RN takes a prudent fiscal stance given the strong incentive of winning 2027 Presidential race and therefore under such a scenario we expect 10Y France-Germany spread to settle in 70- 80bp range. Clearly, if RN decides to take a confrontational fiscal approach, it would be quite disruptive.

In our view, the less likely scenarios of a left coalition government (either relative or absolute majority) are the most disruptive outcomes under a new lower house election scenario given their expansive fiscal agenda. We expect French spreads to come under significant pressure with 10Y France- Germany spread potentially widening beyond 100bp.
Figure 8: Market focus expected to remain on the fiscal agenda under various outcomes J.P. Morgan estimate of market reaction under various French political scenarios;

Likelihood/ Probabilities10Y France-Germany spread* over next 1-2MBayrou govt. survive confidence vote10-20%60-65bpBayrou govt. falls80-90%-New PM without election55%65-75bpNew lower house election40%-RN: relative majority govtmost likely75-85bpRN: absolute majority govtless likely70-80bpCentrist coalition: relative majority govtlikely60-65bpCentrist coalition: absolute majority govtunlikely&lt;60bpLeft coalition: relative majority govtless likely&gt;100bpLeft coalition: absolute majority govtunlikely&gt;100bpMacron resigns5%&gt;100bp
\\*OAT May35 vs. Bund Aug34; current level:79bp Source: J.P. Morgan

On the ratings front, France has a busy rating review calendar post summer (Figure 9). Fitch will be the first to review French sovereign rating on 12 September (current rating AA- negative outlook). Fitch had put France on negative outlook in October 2024. In their last rating review in March 2025, Fitch had forecast French deficit for 2026 at \(5.6\%\) and for 2027 at \(5.4\%\) . Also, in their recent commentary post the French 2026 draft proposal from the Bayrou government in July 2025, Fitch highlighted that the proposed budget (2026 deficit projected at \(4.6\%\) by the government) could improve fiscal outturns but given political constraints the government will find it hard to approve the proposal in full. Our base case is for no rating action from Fitch at the review, as by 12 September, it is unlikely to have much clarity on political/budget process and Fitch will likely want to see the final political/budget outcome before making a decision on a rating downgrade. A rating downgrade from AA- to A+ will be a modest surprise for the market, in our view, and would likely lead to some modest knee- jerk widening in French spreads (around 5bp in 10Y spread). For instance, Belgian spreads underperformed by around 4bp vs. core peers post the Fitch down

grade from AA- negative outlook to \(\mathrm{A + }\) stable outlook on 13 June 2025. A downgrade to \(\mathrm{A + }\) will have no direct index implications (in terms of exclusion) for the key bond indices, as per our understanding. A downgrade from AA to the A bucket (not our base case) could lead to some selling as some investors could have an internal hurdle rate with AA as a minimum rating threshold for investments. However, it is hard to estimate the magnitude of these flows given the lack of public data on these benchmarks.

Over the near term, we find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia broadly fair in the French spreads and expect the 10Y France- Germany spread to stay in 75- 85bp range over the coming weeks till there is some clarity on the direction of the political developments. We have been recommending partly hedging our OW exposures in 10Y EU and 10Y Belgium with UW France over the past few months to benefit from any potential French political noise. These recommendations performed well over this week's French widening. We take profit on OW 10Y Belgium \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) (Figure 10). We keep OW 10Y EU \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) given our medium- term constructive EU outlook also.
Figure 9: France has a busy rating review calendar post summer but we don't expect any ratings changes until there is more clarity on the political backdrop

Italian spreads broadly widened during the risk- off move, reverting back to mid- July levels. We still continue to find risk- reward in Italian OW exposures quite poor, particularly amid increased French political uncertainty. We hold 3s/10s Italy steepener vs. Germany as a low beta risk- off proxy. Over the past two weeks, the box steepened, but continues to screen modestly too flat regressed vs. level of spreads (Figure 11). Further out, the 10s/30s Italy- Germany box continues to exhibit strong negative directionality vs. level of 10Y yield and is currently screening \(\sim 2\mathrm{bp}\) too flat (Figure 12).
Figure 11: Since our last publication, the 3s/10s Italian credit curve continued to steepen, but still screens modestly too flat regressed vs. 10Y Italy- Germany spread
3s/10s Italy- Germany box regressed against 10Y Italy- Germany spread; par rates used; past 6M; bp
Figure 12: The 10s/30s Italy-Germany box continues to exhibit strong negative directionality vs. level of 10Y yield, and is currently screening \(\sim 2bp\) too flat
\(^{*}10s / 30s\) Italy- Germany curve \(= - 13.12^{*}10Y\) Italy yield \(^+\) 80.66; R- sqr \(= 81\%\) Source: J.P. Morgan

In Portugal, during the recent widening move the 7Y sector underperformed relative to surrounding sectors (Figure 13). We see high chances of Portugal syndicating a 7Y benchmark over coming weeks, and, therefore, expect the sector to remain under pressure going forward.
Figure 13: We see high chances of Portugal syndicating a 7Y benchmark over coming weeks, and, therefore, expect the sector to remain under pressure going forward

We expect around €26bn of conventional bond supply next week (Figure 14). Conventional auctions are scheduled in Germany, France and Spain (Figure 15). France will launch a new 10Y benchmark (OAT Nov35) via auction. Also, Belgium has an ORI window scheduled for 5 September and will announce on 4 September if it is planning to use the window or not.
Figure 14: We expect around €26bn of conventional bond supply next week

Figure 15: Conventional auctions next week are scheduled in Germany, France and Spain Euro area conventional bond issuance calendar until the end of September; official announcements and J.P. Morgan forecast; peripheral supply highlighted in grey, green bonds are marked in green; Ebn

Since early August, the 2Y German benchmark outperformed on the German curve relative to surrounding old Bunds and is currently trading with a benchmark discount of around 1.9bp. This is well below the average benchmark discount observed since early 2022 (\~5.4bp) and is close to the long run average benchmark discount observed since early 2012 (Figure 16).
Figure 16: The 2Y German benchmark is currently trading with a benchmark discount of around 1.9bp relative to surrounding old Bands, broadly fair in our view
Benchmark discount\* on 2Y Schatz; bp
\\*Benchmark discount is calculated as the difference between 2Y benchmark (Schatz) yield and interpolated yield calculated using surrounding Bands Source: J.P. Morgan

The 10Y German benchmark is currently trading with a benchmark roll (z- spread pick- up over the off- the- run Feb35) of around 1.5bp, below the average observed since early 2022 ( \(\sim 2.2\) bp), dear in our view (Figure 17). The 10Y German benchmark roll has shown modest negative directionality to 5s/30s German swap spread curve over long history and the Bund Aug35 benchmark roll looks expensive based on that relationship (Figure 18).
Figure 17: The 10Y German benchmark is currently trading with a benchmark roll of around 1.5bp, below the average observed since early 2022
\\*Benchmark roll is defined as z-spread pick-up over off-the-run benchmark Source: J.P. Morgan
Figure 18: 10Y German benchmark-roll has shown modest negative directionality to 5s/30s German swap spread curve over long history and is trading on the expensive side
New OAT Nov35: expect around 4.5- 5.5bp z- spread roll over May35

On Thursday, the French DMO will launch the new OAT Nov35 via auction. Historically, new 10Y French benchmarks have been issued with a benchmark roll (z- spread pick- up over off- the- run) broadly in line to \(\sim 2\) bp higher vs. benchmark roll of existing 10Y benchmark at the time of the new 10Y issuance. With the current 10Y benchmark OAT May35 trading with a benchmark roll at around 4.1bp, we expect the new 10Y OAT Nov35 to follow a similar pattern, and to be issued at around 4.5- 5.5bp benchmark roll (z- spread pick- up over May35). Historically, the newly issued 10Y OAT benchmark roll on average modestly richened in the days following the auction (Figure 19).
Figure 19: The newly issued 10Y OAT benchmark roll on average modestly richened in the days following the auction

The 15Y French benchmark outperformed surrounding bonds on the French curve over the past week and is now trading with a benchmark discount of around 2.1bp, in line with the average benchmark discount observed since the bond first issuance in late January ( \(\sim 2.0\) bp), broadly fair in our view (Figure 20).
Figure 20: The 15Y benchmark discount outperformed surrounding bonds on the French curve over the past week
Evolution of OAT May42 benchmark discount (z- spread); since bond first issuance in late January; bp
OAT May56: modestly cheap

The 30Y French benchmark is currently trading with a benchmark roll (z- spread pick- up over the off- the- run May55) of around 3.7bp, above the average benchmark roll observed over the past 12M ( \(\sim 3.2\mathrm{bp}\) ), modestly cheap in our view.
The Bono Jul28 is currently trading broadly fair on the Spanish curve based on our par curve fair value model.

The 7Y Spanish benchmark is currently trading with a benchmark discount on the Spanish curve of around 1.9bp relative to surrounding bonds, broadly in line with the average benchmark discount observed over the past 6M ( \(\sim 2.1\mathrm{bp}\) ), broadly fair in our view.
The Bono Jan37 is currently trading cheap on the Spanish curve based on our yield vs. modified duration framework.
